content.description: Climb the slab with some marginal gear to the 'crevasse' or traverse left on the crevasse. Step across to gain the offwidth crack then get your knee stuck to a two bolt anchor at the top.
content.protection: #5-6 BD cams could protect it or a tipped out #4 may provide some help. Otherwise TR or run it out.
content.location: At the top of the slab to the right of Annie's Lament, find the prominent knee width crack to the top. Approach either by the 5.8 dirty slab, Annie's Lament, or by scrambling up the gully up and right from the corner of Annie's Lament.

content.description:
Two bolt dirty slab.

Descent: walk off the gully to the right of the route and back down to the base.
content.protection: Two bolts. Runout to the top or fiddle some crappy pro into the crack. Gear anchor.
content.location: Bolted line just to the right of Annie's Lament. Only bolted route on this lower face.

content.description: Good slabby route, clean and well protected.
content.protection: Four bolts? Bolted anchors with rap rings.
content.location: To the right of the large moat on the east face.

content.description: Very dirty slab. Three bolts. Two bolt anchor.
content.location: Walk past Annie's Lament and then scramble up a gully to the east face slabs.

content.description: Dirty slab to the right of the cleaner Neanderthal and Homo Erectus routes on the east slab. In need of some cleaning. Three bolts to a two bolt anchor with rap rings.
content.location: Walk around past Annie's Lament uphill and scramble up a large crack to get on the large ledge to climb the east slab routes.

content.description:
Hand crack to the left of Dirty Boulevard and to the right of Dime Store Mystery. Starts with a committing step across from a large boulder to a good flake. Then the crux is gaining the crack from here. These cruxy early moves can be protected by stick clipping a #3 BD cam into the crack above. Climb up the slightly right leaning well protected hand crack to a bolt at the top of the crack. Finish on dirty slab to a set of bolted anchors about ten feet above the bolt or continue to the top for the full experience.

Descent: Can rappel or lower from bolted anchors with rap rings or can walk off the northwest gully.
content.protection: One bolt. #2 BD cams very useful. #3 for the start and some mid-size cams. Small cams and passive pro not as helpful. One bolt. Bolted anchors.
content.location: Walk up the main trail and when you get to the rock go left. When you are standing at the base of Dragon's breath, a bolted line at the southwest corner, look to the left to a gully with some logs shoved in it. Climb the logs and ascend the slab above. The route is a slightly right leaning hand crack across from a large boulder with about a 4 foot gap between.

content.description: Climb the diagonal crack out left under a roof. Follow final easy slab to bolted anchors on face above climb.
content.protection: Gear to 3", nut tool to landscape.
content.location: Confusing approach. Follow the main approach trail around to the right of the rock and below the large boulders. When the trail is below a large roof, scramble up a class 3 gully to the left and back toward Echo Slab and along the face until you reach the deep drop between Echo Slab and the start of Lost Echos.

content.description:
Good hard slab. Bad feet, nearly no hand holds. Slightly harder than Neanderthal to the right. Four bolts. Bolted anchors.

Could toprope if ascended the standard walk off but would involve some jankiness.
content.protection: Four bolts. Bolted anchors with rap rings.
content.location: Slab to the right of the moat on the east face.

content.description: Begins to the left of a large crack. Head up to the tree. Pull easy roof, follow runout dike into a moat. Belay from the moat. Walk off through moat or climb pitch two of Annie's Lament. Old book has it at 10.b but I thought it felt easier. 5.9?
content.protection: 6 bolts, gear to 3.5". Runners are useful for horns. No anchor chains in the moat.
content.location: Left of Annie's Lament. East Shoulder of Elk Rock. Slabby gray face before the trail starts increasing in grade.

content.description: Well brushed steep slab at the lower corner of the west face. Horizontal edge to diagonal seam protected with a bolt. Climb to the steep hueco covered wall above. 5 bolts and large cams. Chain anchor.
content.protection: 5 bolts and gear, two bolt anchor for lowering.
content.location: The bottom corner of the west face.

content.description: Friction slab up past a bolt. Gear through a bulge to another bolt, then easy runout climbing to bolted anchors at the top.
content.protection: One bolt. Then passive #2 BD cam, then red tricam in pocket, then bolt, then #3 C4 to protect easy final runout. Bolted anchors with rap rings.
content.location: From the main approach trail, when you hit the wall, trace alongside the wall to the right around a corner between the large boulders and the rock. The route is the slab to the left of this wall before you hit a deep gully between the boulders and the wall.

content.description:
Face climb to the right of Mom's Meatfloaf. Step across gully next to the lowest large boulder. Move can be protected with stick clipping the first bolt. Bolted anchor at top.

Descent: rappel from anchor
content.location: Right of Mom's Meatloaf. See approach on Mom's Meatloaf page.

content.description: Start's left of Mom's Meatloaf. Climb bolted face (5.8) then cross wide crack and head up left on dike. 5.8 variation stays in the wide crack after the face section.
content.protection: 4 bolts, gear to 4", bolted chain anchors.
content.location: To the left of Mom's meatloaf. See beta for approach for Mom's Meatloaf.

content.description:
Begin on the distinct layback crack splitting the low angle eastern face of the cliff. Traverse left to avoid the roof and belay at a low angle ledge.

Pitch 2: Continue left climbing over some blobby face. Step across the rock moat. Run it out up the easy slab and belay anywhere convenient.

Variation: Deviating to the right at the small roof puts you in a finger to hand crack which is a blast, but probably goes slightly harder than 5.6. This route can easily be done in one pitch with a 70m rope and possibly a 60m rope. Just mind rope drag low down.
content.protection:
Pitch 1: Gear to 4 inches...Tri-Cams, TCU's, and long runners useful. Two bolts on the left side above the roof.

Pitch 2: Can sling horns for protection, but 5.0 climbing.

Can link both pitches into one long pitch.

Can use large tree at top for anchor or two bolts with rap rings to the right of the tree on the face.
content.location: Walk around to the east shoulder slabs and begin on the distinct layback crack splitting the low angle face. Walk off by scrambling down the gully on the north western side of the crag. Can also rappel to the huge ledge and walk off climbers right from there.
